text.div:
Severely Obese Adults 2018 Norwegian Cohort
Cohort study with baseline data of exposures from November 2005 through July 2010 and follow-up data from 2006 until death or through December 2015 at a tertiary care outpatient center, Vestfold Hospital Trust, Norway. Consecutive treatment-seeking adult patients (n = 2109) with severe obesity assessed (221 patients excluded and 1888 patients included).

text.div: Risk of Remission of diabetes in control group was 14.8%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Remission of diabetes without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of Remission of diabetes in intervention group was 57.5%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Remission of diabetes with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
greater likelihood of diabetes remission: AR, 57.5% vs 14.8%; RD, 42.7% [95% CI, 35.8%-49.7%], RR, 3.9 [95% CI, 2.8-5.4]
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to induce remission of diabetes.

text.div: Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in intervention group was 31.3%. 292 out of 932 observed with percentage of: 31.3%

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Additional GI surgical procedure with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
Surgical patients had a greater risk for undergoing at least 1 additional gastrointestinal surgical procedure (AR, 31.3% vs 15.5%; RD, 15.8% [95% CI, 13.1%-18.5%]; RR, 2.0 [95% CI, 1.7-2.4]).
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to increase the rate of additional gastrointestinal surgical procedures.
